Have a look at the tabview bar above to see a single level sticky in action.

First level of stickiness

Multiple levels can be sticky.

First level of stickiness

Adhesion is the tendency of dissimilar particles or surfaces to cling to one another (cohesion refers to the tendency of similar or identical particles/surfaces to cling to one another).

Second level of stickiness

The forces that cause adhesion and cohesion can be divided into several types.

Third level of stickiness

The intermolecular forces responsible for the function of various kinds of stickers and sticky tape fall into the categories of chemical adhesion, dispersive adhesion, and diffusive adhesion.

Fourth level of stickiness

In addition to the cumulative magnitudes of these intermolecular forces, there are certain emergent mechanical effects that will also be discussed at the end of the article.

Fifth level of stickiness

Surface energy is conventionally defined as the work that is required to build a unit area of a particular surface.

Sixth level of stickiness

Another way to view the surface energy is to relate it to the work required to cleave a bulk sample, creating two surfaces.
